ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: basic level Korean
I gained a better understanding of how to write and communicate in Korean
A lot of Korean and Korean Culture!

How to address people formally
Making plans
Describing something to do in the future
Writing letters
Konglish
Adjectives 
Weather
Asking for help
Can/cant
If
I might

And much more!
More advanced Korean grammar and vocabulary. I have been able to hold simple conversations with folks after taking this course.
I strengthened the Korean skills I gained in Korean 110. I feel like I understand the grammatical structure of Korean better, and I feel more comfortable speaking the language.
More vocabulary and grammar that contributed to greater speaking engagement.
Learned how to read and write in Hanggul, have basic conversations and presentations
I developed an advanced understanding of the language of Korean. I learned cultural norms along with customs and traditions. I was able to expand my worldly knowledge with this course.
I improved (hopefully) in my ability to read, write, and speak Korean.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: personally, I'm not the biggest fan of learning foreign languages and found Korean extremely difficult. However, Professor Lim makes this course great. He is genuinely the best part of this course as his teaching, kindness, and overall enthusiasm is what made me enjoy this course.
AMAZING!!

Interesting subject matter
Made learning Korean feel easy

No weaknesses but wish we learned adjectives and colors earlier on

I do not have any comments about improvement. I think the course does a good job of teaching you what you should know for L2 Korean. It is just quickly paced, and you do learn much grammar and vocab each day, so you have to learn how to keep up with the new material regularly.
The course was excellent, and I enjoyed it greatly.
The workbook lessons were useful in reinforcing vocabulary and sentence structures but I would have appreciated a more structured schedule to it

I feel as if the 50 minute period every day is not enough time to truly engage with the language. As for strengths, it does provide complex sentence structure and grammatical understanding of the language.

This course was great at building and increasing comfort with the language in a safe environment. I think the class was less stringent than intro classes in other languages would be, although I don't think that is a weakness considering the difficulty for many students of learning a language with an entirely different script.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely if you want to learn entry-level Korean and the basics

YES! Professor Lim is AMAZING! The best. One of my best professors at Yale so far.

Sweet, FUNNY!, engaging, and caring.
Absolutely! Very fun class and you learn a lot quickly even if the beginning seems overwhelming

I would highly recommend this course to another student because it is fun to learn and practice Korean with your classmates. You have lots of opportunities to practice in class, and out of the East Asian languages, I would say Korean is the easiest to learn.

I would recommend the course to anyone seeking to gain a foundation in Korean. There's a lot of new material every day and it can sometimes be difficult to remember it all, but the class itself is very chill and supportive. It's everything a language class should be.
In my personal experience, Korean has been the "easiest" foreign language to learn and Professor Lim has made it an incredibly enjoyable experience.
Yes, it is a great introductory course that will teach plenty of content.
This course is a great continuation of KREN 110; you are able to further develop the language and actually communicate in a way that you couldn't in L1.
Any student who wants to learn Korean or a foreign language in general should absolutely take the chance to learn with the Korean department at Yale.
